text: The Shrimp Girl is an oil painting by William Hogarth. It was painted between 1740 and 1745. It measures 63.5 x 52.5 cm. It hangs in the National Gallery, London.Mark Hallett and Christine Riding (2006). Hogarth. Tate Publishing Ltd, pp.126–127. . The brush work is almost Impressionistic in style. It compares to that of French painter Jean-Honoré Fragonard. Its subject matter resembles the prints of hawkers and traders popular in Hogarth's day.Jonathan Jones, The Shrimp Girl, William Hogarth (c1745), The Guardian, 15 September 2001. The painting depicts a woman selling shellfish on the streets of London. This job was typically one for the wives and daughters of fishmongers. The girl balances a large basket of shrimps and mussels on her head. A half-pint pewter pot in the basket is the girl's measuring cup. The picture is not strictly finished. It was still in Hogarth's estate after his death. His widow Jane was said to have told visitors, "They say he could not paint flesh. There is flesh and blood for you."The Shrimp Girl: about 1740–5, William Hogarth, National Gallery, London, UK. The pictue was only sold after his wife's death in 1789. It first received its title The Shrimp Girl in a Christie's sale catalog. == References == Category:1740s paintings Category:Paintings by William Hogarth Category:Paintings in the National Gallery, London
title: The Shrimp Girl
